OP, I just wanted to pop in and offer some support. I went through the same thing about just over a year ago, and had to have the LEEP procedure. I was 26 at the time. It was super stressful and I have totally been in your shoes. A couple of things that helped me: my OBGYN recommended I start taking a supplement called Oncovite, which I started taking before the procedure... when they biopsied the tissue they removed from me, my doc told me that the abnormal cells were gone, and I‚Äôve had clear paps ever since. I absolutely know everyone has a different experience and no two bodies are the same, but I wanted to share some of my experience and offer a bit of hope. Secondly, I strongly believe that my aggressive efforts to drastically minimize the stress in my life played a huge role in keeping me healthy. I was also working as a designer, and also had dreams of becoming a freelance photographer full-time. I think my job was putting invisible stress on me, and ironically when I did quit that job and start freelancing (which is what I do now, full time) it took away the stress...I think because I am earning more, even though it isn‚Äôt a ‚Äústeady‚Äù paycheck.  It is incredible what stress can do to the body, and we have to take care of our whole selves.

Please, please, please make sure to have regular anal exams in addition to vaginal exams and cervical Pap smears. I had multiple abnormal Pap‚Äôs and LEEP procedures 15 years ago and was recently diagnosed with anal cancer, which is also caused by HPV.  I never had any anal exams because I wasn‚Äôt practicing anal sex so the cancer had been growing there all these years.  If you haven‚Äôt already, get the HPV vaccine. It‚Äôs FDA approved for women to age 45 now. I‚Äôve had surgery and radiation and the cancer might still come back. All of this could have been completely prevented.
OP here, results came back benign and I'm back to just going in for my yearly pap :) much love and thx for all the concerns and support xoxo

Hi OP! I‚Äôm sorry you had to go through such a painful/annoying medical procedure twice, not to mention deal with the fear and uncertainty.   I just want to say, there‚Äôs no such thing as an ‚Äúimmune boosting diet‚Äù. Any diet that claims to boost your immune system is pseudoscience. There are of course plenty of other reasons to eat vitamin-filled fruits and veggies, as well as lean protein sources, so there‚Äôs no harm in that.   I totally understand wanting to try something that claims to boost your immune system or claims to be ‚Äúanti-cancer.‚Äù  Illness and cancer are scary, and it would be nice to think we could cure them with magic diets. It just doesn‚Äôt work that way (though certain cancers.. eg colon cancer.. are linked to certain less healthy diets).   I hope you got the answers you wanted from your colposcopy. Also don‚Äôt be afraid to switch doctors to find one who talks to you more. Listening to your patients is arguably one of the most important things for a doctor to do.

In my mid-20's I had several abnormal paps and got diagnosed with strains 16 and 18 of HPV. Also had a colonoscopy and was given all of the general advice about the body naturally clearing HPV. I'm now 30 and the last few paps I've had have been clear!  One thing that I don't see mentioned in this thread and that finally clicked for me was that even if you are taking all of the vitamins in this world, reducing your stress etc. if you're still sleeping with the same guy and not using condoms, chances are that you will continue to be reinfected with the HPV.  My gyno had advised me that I should be using condoms with my boyfriend, at least until I'd cleared the virus, I ignored her advice at that time. It wasn't until I broke up with the boyfriend I was with during my abnormal paps that I noticed that all my paps since about 6 months post breakup have been clear. Honestly everything else about my lifestyle and health has stayed the same.  This might be obvious, but I wanted to share what I've learned from my own experience (and lack of listening to professionals in the first place!) in case it makes a difference to someone going through the stress of abnormal paps :)

OP, I immediately stopped reading to comment when I got done with day one. I'm 25, and have been getting abnormal pap smears for the last several years because I have high-risk HPV. I have strains 16 and 18, the two strains that have the highest possibility to make my cervical cells become cancerous. I'm surprised that you had a colposcopy done at 23‚Äîthat's pretty young, and most gynos don't recommend those until you're at least 25 because your immune system is stronger when you're younger. I got my first colposcopy done this year, and it was the scariest thing I've ever had to do. My results from my colposcopy (to make a very long, boring story short) stated that even though I have abnormal cells on my cervix, they're pretty much dormant, so I just need to get a pap smear done every year. As scary and terrifying abnormal paper smears are,I want you to know that it honestly is totally normal. You're doing the right thing in getting it checked out and monitored though. The more you stay on top of it, the higher your recovery is IF they find something in the future. I do want to also reassure you just because you have abnormal cells on your cervix, that doesn't mean that you're GOING to get cervical cancer. It just means those cells COULD. COULD doesn't mean WILL. As long as you're taking good care of yourself, eating right, exercising, doing things to boost your immune system, and going to regular doctor's appointments, I PROMISE you you will be okay. :-) You've got this!

OP here! I did notice I forgot to mention a few things :) I cleared up some horse money questions in the comments below! Also, my health insurance is 100% employer paid. I'm super grateful for that and being able to get off my family's insurance plan early! I contribute 55$ a month with my employer matching that = $110 a month to my HSA. I use this to cover my monthly chiropractor visits (Back pain, am I right?) and the leftover I plan to invest. My company offers investment plans at the end of each fiscal year to invest "left over" money from your HSA and I plan to take full advantage of that. My retirement is currently 3% of my income for now. I plan to up that come fall. As apart of my hire, I started at $50k a year and in 6 months (September) receive a $5k raise, so that will put my annual salary at $55,000 a year. They will reevaluate my income and put in for another raise once I graduate. I started at my company in June of 2019 as an intern, caught on very quickly, and got the opportunity to come on full time!   You all have been so amazing and supportive in the comments section! I love interacting with everyone and hearing questions or their stories! :)

I suggest doing something in a group regularly as a good way to make friends. Showing up week after week allows you the time to build a friendship, and a common topic to discuss. Sport, volunteering, an adult education course, I speak from experience, are all good ways of making friends.

I'm a 22 year old and I've also noticed that it's hard to make friends my own age in a new place. I think a big factor is that in your early 20s, many people in the area have been there since high school/college, and thus already have established friend groups. As you get older, more people start to move around, and there are more people your age looking for new friends.

Hi OP! I know you mention anxiety/depression and I struggle with same. Have you considered limiting or cutting out alcohol and caffeine? I'm not saying this with a preachy or judgy tone at all. I know different things work for different people. It did help me quite a bit personally so that's the only reason I'm throwing this out there. :)

Something I'll never understand is congratulating someone for working long hours, especially for relatively low pay. Why? She didn't mention that her work brings her so much joy that she truly can't leave and go home.   Doesn't matter if you're a lawyer, but for salaried workers, you're setting up the expectation that one person can do the job of two or more people, giving away your free time and making your hourly wage so much lower if you typically work 60 hours/week. What's the glory in that?  Edited to add: this comment doesn't apply for workers who get overtime pay or comp time in exchange for working beyond 40 hours/week.

Is it just me or do her monthly expenses as listed total up to more than her take home salary at the end of the month? Perhaps she doesn't actually put as much towards savings every single month as she says, but still that stuff always irks me because it's setting up such a different picture on the outset than what's actually real.   That being said, I loved this MD! Great picture of a mid-30s gal in the city, and OP seemed like someone I'd love to grab a drink and be friends with. I do think that OP realizes overall how great her privilege is at not having any debt and owning her apartment. It might be forgotten in moments where she expects her friends in Big Law to cover more of the tab (while forgetting that although they may have huge salaries, many of them probably also have huge huge debt and less overall privileges than she does.)But alas, we're all human and we all have our moments. OP, you're great. Continue being you.

R29: the "net worth" field as-is is pretty darn useless.  it seems no one really knows how to calculate it. refer to the diarists with 200K+ in student and consumer debt who then have a positive net worth listed. unless these people somehow also have hundreds of thousands of equity in their homes or massive trust funds, this can't possibly be right.  what would be much more meaningful (and likely more consistently calculated) is an inventory of assets. for example, here she says she has $100K net worth. is that tied up in a home she owns? 401K? liquid assets? did she inherit it? saying "my net worth is $100k" is not at all useful information in painting a financial picture...especially for a 25 year old making $80k a year

I heard an NPR article about the banks "deferring" mortgages for people - apparently some banks are requiring that the deferred amount be paid in a lump sum (a "balloon payment") at the end of the deferral period (which could be as short as 3 months). This is just as unhelpful to homeowners as it is to renters, unfortunately.   I think everyone's got a hardship right now - homeowners have mortgage issues, renters have rent issues, hell even frontline workers have issues working the frontline!  OP - maybe you can ask your landlord to spread the month's payment over the rest of your lease? Easier to handle vs a balloon payment to be sure. To people who don't live in SF, rent stabilized isn't the same as rent control. Rents in most buildings can only go up a small percentage every year (this time it was 1.8%). So if they're paying $1300, one of them has lived there for 5+ years. If they move out, the landlord will rent out the unit at a higher price, likely higher than $2k. She is NOT pushing people out of the city. Rent control actually protects lower income San Franciscans.

Fellow user of out-of-network therapists here: just wanted to note what I recently found out about coverage for out-of-network services after you hit your deductible.  Although your plan probably states 70% covered, it usually means 70% of the <strong allowable amount</strong  is covered.  The allowable amount is usually calculated by reference to the Medicare rates for services (multiplied by some amount, e.g., 120%, 130%).  That's a long way of saying to prepare for the fact that insurance might not cover 70% of your $185 therapy sessions.  It might be closer to 70% of $120 - depends on how your sessions are coded.

https://www.refinery29.com/en-us/2020/04.comment_text: it's frustrating to see people conflate social distancing with quarantining. Social Distancing is for the majority of the populace that don't have COVID, have no known exposure, etc. This is to keep healthy people healthy, and flatten the curve. Quarantining is for people with COVID, people with known exposure to COVID, people travelling from infection hot spots, etc. This is to cut off the virus from spreading outside those already infected/exposed. OP should have been quarantining, full stop. Social Distancing is not enough for someone who has daily close contact with people that are infected; those people need to essentially be sealed off from the rest of the population for 14 days (although I'm not 100% clear on if it's 14 days from diagnosis, 14 days from the onset of symptoms, or 14 days since the symptoms have stopped?) I know that everyone feels and handles things differently and is entitled to do so. This is not a criticism, but I didn't understand why OP was so stressed and overwhelmed. She is is in a supportive and loving relationship. She is on her way to owning a house in one of the world's most sought after and beautiful cities. She has no children to worry over and care for. She hates her job, as sadly many, many people do. But her job allows her to work from home and leave most days at 5:00. She has leisure time for reading books and friends. At age 31, her salary is much higher than the average 50 year old's salary. Her commute is challenging, but as are many people's commutes, whether stuck in cars for long periods of time, hoping to fend off road rage incidents or crammed into commuter trains and buses praying not to contact COVID 19. Most commenters seem to agree that OP's life is stressful. What am I missing? Maybe I'm just envious; but I would love to have her problems, in comparison to the ones I or those around me have.

OP hereeee I saw a couple questions asking for updates. My school updated us and now we are indefinitely postponed. They said that we will get the "green light" once local schools re-open, then teachers will have 3 weeks to get back to Chengdu. My fiance is still displaced in the south of China and the plan is for him to go back to Chengdu this month, update me, and I will make my way back. Those $280 tickets I scouted are now over $900 which makes me think I missed my window to get back to Chengdu.  This outbreak is going nuts in the US right now (deja vu?) and today is the day my siblings drove into town and we are remembering my mom. One sister and husband decided they will stay here for a week or as long as they need to (working from home). The other and her husband are heading back because his work isn't cancelled (.. yet! We have a bet).  I couldn't just take more students or rearrange my schedule because people who have been in lockdown in China and not working are not dishing out $$$ for online tutoring. Thankful for my normal paycheck+the editing+barebones of tutoring.  The wedding might be off? We still don't know. Hey OP, enjoyed this diary and your honesty about getting your finances in order! It's not easy to acknowledge areas that need some work and it sounds like you're doing a great job getting on top of it- awesome!  Just a tip that's worked for me: Try setting up your paycheck so that at least a small amount is deposited into a different account, or even multiple accounts. It's such an easy way to save money without trying, AND it psychologically makes you feel like you have less play money to spend in your checking account. Also it seems like the student loans/CC debt doesn't have to be an either/or thing...for example you could divert $250 of each paycheck into a separate account just to start chipping away at that. Best of luck, you're doing great!

Hi! OP here. Wow, you think you've spent all this time and effort on a money diaries and then you read it and realize how much you missed!  Some stuff:  1) I invest 15% towards retirement (pre-tax) 2) I receive $2,400 a year from a family member for my student loans which I just received, so I now have 3K left. I have a CC debt snowball for the credit cards and have done a pretty good job of strategically timing out my payments so that by I'm CC debt free by Oct 2021, well before my 0% APR hits. I'm choosing to pay my student loans off first because I have a huge fear that I won't be able to get my shit together regarding my spending and I'm just afraid that I'll get myself out of CC debt and then slide right back in. At least my student loans will be GONE in 4 months. I recognize how tenuous it seems and honestly I have a lot of shame around this, but I'm doing really good in regards to working on this.  3) I did stop home for 30 minutes to hang with my dog between work & the shelter! She also has my roommate & her bf at home for some socialization. But I do feel bad for these long days.  4) My insurance is under my mom, which probably helps with the lower cost.
